question: What lake in Australia is named after a Scottish Knight?
responder_answer: Lake St. Clair in New South Wales, Australia, is named after a Scottish noble family, the St. Clairs, who were historically associated with knighthood. The lake's name derives from the Clan St. Clair, a Scottish family with knighted members, though specific attribution to an individual knight is not well-documented. The name reflects Scottish heritage in the region's naming conventions.

Lake St. Clair in New South Wales, Australia, is named after the St. Clair homestead, which was submerged when Glennies Creek Dam was constructed in 1983. Historical records indicate the lake’s name originates from the homestead, not an individual Scottish knight. The St. Clair family name itself derives from a Scottish clan (Sinclair/St. Clair), but no specific knight is documented as the namesake. The Singleton Council and Wikipedia confirm the dam’s purpose and naming history, with no evidence linking the lake to a particular Scottish knight. 

<references>
1. [Singleton Council - Lake St Clair](https://www.singleton.nsw.gov.au/Experience/Facilities-and-Recreation/Lake-St-Clair)
2. [Glennies Creek Dam - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glennies_Creek_Dam)
</references>

question: What lake in Australia is named after a Scottish Knight?
responder_answer: Lake George in New South Wales, Australia, was named after King George III of the United Kingdom, not a Scottish knight. However, Lake Torrens in South Australia was named by the explorer Edward John Eyre in 1839 after Colonel Robert Torrens, who was the chairman of the South Australian Colonization Commission. Sir Thomas Livingstone Mitchell, a Scottish explorer and surveyor, named Lake Bonney in South Australia after Charles Bonney, but Bonney was not a Scottish knight. There is no major Australian lake directly named after a Scottish knight, but some are named after people of Scottish heritage or title holders. If you are looking for a very specific, lesser-known lake or a different spelling, further details would help.
revisor_answer:
Lake Macquarie in New South Wales, Australia, is named after Major-General Lachlan Macquarie, who was the Governor of New South Wales from 1810 to 1821. Lachlan Macquarie was born on the Isle of Ulva, Scotland, and was knighted, thus bearing the title “Sir Lachlan Macquarie.” Therefore, Lake Macquarie is the prominent Australian lake named after a Scottish knight.
